title: Are there any good books on early European history from origins up to Medieval times? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are thousands of good books on European history from the Neolithic up to the Renaissance, but I wonder what kind of good you expect the books to be. I mean many books are “Good Reads”, but aren’t very detailed or accurate or they avoid treating the history of the interactions between European people and people from other places and cultures. I for one couldn’t do with those books, since I am a fifth generation inhabitant of one of Europe’s most historically important port cities (Antwerp, Belgium). My city has been multi-cultural for over 400 years, and my family tree has branches in other Port cities, through marriages, like in Piraeus, Greece (Uncle Dimitri), in Annaba, Algeria (Uncle Rachid), and in Copacabana (Uncle Armand). That is Greek (Russian) Orthodox Christian culture, Arab Islamic culture, and Latin-American Catholic culture that I wouldn’t have wanted to miss out on. That is why I have always preferred the “Academic Works”, over the “Good Reads”, even though the former are clearly less entertaining than the latter. I have to read them with my computer on stand-by, so that I can look up meanings of words. I mean it is all up to you and to what you want to learn about. All cultures of the world started writing their histories as “centre of the world” or even as “the only part of the world that really matters” or as “a culture of important people, not women.” I would suggest you start at the end (Medieval Europe), and not at the beginning (Neolithic Europe), with a rare example of an “Academic Work” that is also a “Good Read”, namely A Distant Mirror, by Barbara W. Tuchman. It is about 14th Century Europe, before and after the “Black Death” (1346–1353), a calamity shared by three continents and all of its cultures. It is a crossroads, in a way, at which Northern Europeans, Mediterranean and Eastern Europeans, East-Asians, Indians, Arabs and Persians, all had to deal with the aftermath of a massive holocaust visited upon them by a an immensely powerful, but faceless and nameless non-human enemy. The book describes how Western European culture changed, but if you know the history of other Euro-Asian-African cultures as well, you will be moved by the similarities. You could say the year 1350 is where world history took one of its most dramatic turns. I promise you will not be disappointed.

Not a book, but there is a very useful Yale Open Course on Youtube dealing with the early Medieval period (fall of Rome onwards) which covers major topics (Constantine, Justinian, the Germanic invasions, Vikings, Rise of Islam etc) You can also get hold of the recommended reading list for the course Good luck with Sy Augustine, by the way While Sophie Dockx’s answer is fascinating and very useful, if you start with the fourteenth century you will be missing out on thousand years of what we regard as ‘Medieval History’ - and a vast amount of what is fundamental to the changes from the classical world to the modern world. So you might wish to cast you net back to the 5th century as a starting point

Tacitus Germania and his Agricola are two of them! Plus south of the Barbarians, you have Romans. Tacitus (whom I have partly read), Cassius Dio, Suetonius (both of whom I have not read), for older Roman Livy, for older Greek Herodotus, then you come to Christian historians, like Socrates (not the philosopher, but a namesake) etc. For just limit to Medieval, read saints’ lives. For instance Vita Sancti Severini by Eugippius.

I have a couple of old paperbacks that you can find by Carlo .M. Cipolla (Fontana Series). The series covered from the early middle ages onwards through to modern capitalism. Here is an in print copy of his work; Before the Industrial Revolution: European Society and Economy, 1000-1700: Carlo M. Cipolla: 9780393311983: Amazon.com: Books You can find the Fontana series in 2nd hand bookshops for as little as a few dollars each.
